awd_titl_txt: Understanding the role of conserved dynamic covalent junctions on block copolymer and network self-assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
Block copolymers are used in many applications such as epoxies, battery electrolytes, and elastic clothing, and are valued for their ability to combine two functions into one material. This ability comes from bonding two or more polymer chains made of different chemical units called monomers. The differing chemical monomers causes the different blocks of the polymer to separate, like oil and water. However, because they are bonded together, the result is small domains, consisting of one block or the other. Forming a regular, ordered pattern of these small domains is challenging as the ordered phases often exhibit defects, or deviations from the pattern, where the polymer chains become trapped. The investigators propose to introduce dynamic links between blocks that will allow some of the block copolymers to exchange their sections with a nearby block copolymer. The investigators hypothesize that this additional freedom will give the system as a whole greater flexibility to achieve long-range order of the different phases. This faster assembly is expected to reduce processing time, energy, and waste. The investigators plan to incorporate lessons about dynamic polymer characterization and molecular simulation into day-camp projects by partnering with the Girls Learning About Materials and the CURIE Camp@Illinois organizations.

This proposal aims to understand the effects of dynamic junctions in block copolymer self-assembly. Including a fraction of exchangeable bonds is expected to increase chain mobility, improve long-range order and reduce time, energy and waste during the annealing process. To test this hypothesis, the investigators will synthesize block copolymer systems that include both permanent and dynamic junctions. Both polystyrene and polyisoprene block copolymers (PS-PI) and polyethylene oxide and polydimethylsiloxane (PEO-PDMS) will be studied at various molecular weights, using small angle x-ray scattering (SAXS) to assess the morphology. The investigators will also model this system using self-consistent field theory. The investigators will also explore the role of additional chains at a dynamic junction, by modeling and characterizing dynamic miktoarm star polymers and contrasting with dynamic diblock copolymers, again using both experimental and computational approaches. The expected outcome of this project are fundamental insights into the role of dynamic on block copolymer self-assembly and mechanisms to reduce kinetically trapped defects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes: CBET-2029928

Title: Understanding the role of conserved dynamic covalent junctions on block copolymer and network self-assembly

PIs: Christopher M. Evans, Charles E. Sing

Intellectual Merit

The self-assembly of polymers to form features on the nanoscale has broad ranging impacts in current and emerging areas such as nanolithography, toughened epoxies, battery electrolytes, and photonic materials. When two distinct, immiscible polymers are covalently linked together, they form diblock copolymers which are known to phase separate on the nanoscale. This project has advanced the fundamental understanding of self-assembly in polymers with two different chemistries attached by a group which can allow the polymers to dynamically rearrange at specific points. Block copolymers (with a dynamic point linking two polymers) and binary networks (with a dynamic point holding together three polymer strands) were investigated in a combined experiment, theory, and simulation approach which showed that dynamic bonds can alter the rate of assembly and the final stable nanoscale structures, compared to conventional polymers with only permanent covalent bonds. In block copolymers, faster dynamic linkages generally lead to faster assembly; however, there is a tradeoff in certain temperature and composition regimes where the mobility of the polymer chains begins to contribute and slow the exchange of strands in the polymer. Adding a catalyst can accelerate the dynamic exchange process and further speed up ordering. In binary networks, the presence of dynamic linkages is shown to fundamentally change the stability criteria for two immiscible polymers. These linkages can make miscible blends out of immiscible starting components because of the role of the dynamic crosslinker and the multiple combinations of attached chains which are possible (junction entropy). 

Broader Impact

Placing dynamic bonds into block copolymers can lead to faster assembly, thus reducing annealing and process times, and potentially lead to highly ordered nanostructures without the need for solvent or thermal treatments. This would substantially reduce energy and waste in multiple application areas. Additionally, there has been a push to impart dynamic bonds into polymers to make them easier to reprocess and manufacture under appropriate conditions. Multicomponent dynamic networks have implications for combining mixed plastic waste streams by making them miscible, a current barrier in plastic reprocessing. Combine polymers of disparate chemistries into miscible blends also opens possibilities for designing stable materials with synergistic properties of the starting components. The ability to nanostructure and re-process networks using simple approaches could broaden the scope of functionality in these systems. Our findings will be disseminated both on campus and to the community through outreach projects including day camps for Girls Learning About Materials and the CURIE Camp@Illinois. Both cases promote interest in STEM fields to high school and middle-school aged students by introducing them to the exciting world of reprocessable and assembled polymeric materials. Programming was developed to combine hands on demonstrations, experience with dynamic polymer characterization, and molecular simulation.

 


Last Modified: 03/07/2025
Modified by: Christopher Evans
